repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body: the name suggests to me that it would ensure `len` in total, not additional `len` space
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -207,6 +207,16 @@ static inline void *_memcpy_free(void *const restrict dest, void *const restrict
   /* 2^x initial array size. */ \
   kvi_resize(v, (v).capacity << 1)
 
+/// fit at least "len" more items
+#define kvi_ensure_space(v, len) \

comment_data.body:
I don't remember this code very well, but do we need both loops? Or at least what is the role of each loop? The old loop just does a scan for a specific row and skips "end" marks.

I guess the first loops covers "range marks" and the second loop handle "point marks"?

> I guess the first loops covers "range marks" and the second loop handle "point marks"?

Basically yes. more specifically the first loop handles all range marks which overlaps the start position `(row, 0)`. the second loop handles ranges which start later in the line, as well as point marks.

Added a comment at `marktree_itr_get_overlap` as the "double loop" pattern is relevant to many call places

```suggestion
  In addition, |nvim_buf_get_extmarks()| has gained an "overlap" option to
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -219,6 +219,14 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
   "virtual_text" table, which gives users more control over how diagnostic
   virtual text is displayed.
 
+• Extmarks now fully supports multi-line ranges, and a single extmark can be
+  used to highlight a range of arbitrary length. The |nvim_buf_set_extmark()|
+  API function already allowed you to define such ranges, but highlight regions
+  was not rendered consistently for a range that covers more than one line break.
+  This has now been fixed. Signs defined as part of a multi-line extmark also
+  applies to every line in the range, not just the first.
+  In addition, |nvim_buf_get_extmarks()| has gained a "overlap" option to

@@ -219,6 +219,14 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
   "virtual_text" table, which gives users more control over how diagnostic
   virtual text is displayed.
 
+• Extmarks now fully supports multi-line ranges, and a single extmark can be
+  used to highlight a range of arbitrary length. The |nvim_buf_set_extmark()|
+  API function already allowed you to define such ranges, but highlight regions
+  was not rendered consistently for a range that covers more than one line break.
+  This has now been fixed. Signs defined as part of a multi-line extmark also
+  applies to every line in the range, not just the first.
+  In addition, |nvim_buf_get_extmarks()| has gained a "overlap" option to
+  return such ranges even if they started before the specified position.
 ==============================================================================

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
• Extmarks now fully support multi-line ranges, and a single extmark can be
  used to highlight a range of arbitrary length. The |nvim_buf_set_extmark()|
  API function already allowed you to define such ranges, but highlight regions
  were not rendered consistently for a range that covers more than one line break.
  This has now been fixed. Signs defined as part of a multi-line extmark also
  apply to every line in the range, not just the first.
  In addition, |nvim_buf_get_extmarks()| has gained an "overlap" option to
  return such ranges even if they started before the specified position.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -221,6 +221,15 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
   "virtual_text" table, which gives users more control over how diagnostic
   virtual text is displayed.
 
+• Extmarks now fully supports multi-line ranges, and a single extmark can be
+  used to highlight a range of arbitrary length. The |nvim_buf_set_extmark()|
+  API function already allowed you to define such ranges, but highlight regions
+  was not rendered consistently for a range that covers more than one line break.
+  This has now been fixed. Signs defined as part of a multi-line extmark also
+  applies to every line in the range, not just the first.
+  In addition, |nvim_buf_get_extmarks()| has gained na "overlap" option to
+  return such ranges even if they started before the specified position.

comment_regular_data.body: This would be really useful to implement "locals" highlighting for tree-sitter. Just to look up the ranges a given point is currently contained in.

This should be ready for testing. The user visible changes should be as described in news.txt 

>  Extmarks now fully supports multi-line ranges, and a single extmark can be
  used to highlight a range of arbitrary length. The |nvim_buf_set_extmark()|
  API function already allowed you to define such ranges, but highlight regions
  was not rendered consistently for a range that covers more than one line break.
  This has now been fixed. In addition, |nvim_buf_get_extmarks()| has gained
  a "overlap" option to return such ranges even if they started before the
  specified position.
@lewis6991 I implemented all the `pending` tests for ranged signs. Note in one case I had to change the ordering of the the signs, does that look fine to you?
Yeah I think that's fine. Neither sign type defines a priority so the ordering shouldn't matter.
Almost three years in the making 🥳

title: feat(extmark): support highlighting and querying multiline ranges
